stem: The labor and delivery nurse is reviewing the electronic fetal monitor (EFM) for four different clients. Based on the documentation, match each fetal heart rate (FHR) pattern description to its appropriate clinical interpretation.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: G1P0 at 41 weeks. Reports decreased fetal movement. Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 4.0 cm (Oligohydramnios).
Patient B: G2P1 at 39 weeks. Cervix 10 cm. Currently pushing.
Patient C: G1P0 at 38 weeks. Noted sharp, abrupt drops in FHR during contractions.
Patient D: G1P0 at 40 weeks. Maternal temperature of 101.8Â°F; foul-smelling amniotic fluid noted.

tabs.title: Fetal Monitoring Summary
tabs.content:
PatientPattern DescriptionBaselineVariability
ALate decelerations; return to baseline after contraction130 bpmMinimal
BEarly decelerations; mirror the contractions145 bpmModerate
CVariable decelerations; V-shaped drops140 bpmModerate
DTachycardia; persistent FHR > 165 bpm170 bpmMinimal

tabs.title: Clinical Background
tabs.content: Patient D: White blood cell count (WBC) 18,000/mm3 (Elevated), indicating suspected Chorioamnionitis.

rows.text: FHR pattern mirrors the contraction (Head Compression)
FHR pattern occurs after the peak of the contraction and returns late (Placental Insufficiency)
Abrupt V-shaped drops in FHR (Umbilical Cord Compression)

rationale.correct: Early decelerations (r1) mirror the contraction and are typically caused by fetal head compression, which is a benign finding (c1). Late decelerations (r2) indicate uteroplacental insufficiency (c2). Variable decelerations (r3) are often caused by umbilical cord compression (c3). Fetal tachycardia (r4) is often the first sign of maternal infection or chorioamnionitis (c4).
clinicalPearls: Fetal tachycardia (>160 bpm) can be an early sign of chorioamnionitis.
Early decelerations generally require no intervention.
Variable decelerations often require maternal position change to relieve cord compression.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing fetal tachycardia with a normal fetal heart rate.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that the normal fetal heart rate range is 110-160 bpm. Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate greater than 160 bpm.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: Variable decelerations - Cord compression; Early decelerations - Head compression; Accelerations - Okay; Late decelerations - Placental insufficiency.
